abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the China Waigaoqiao Thermal
            Power Project were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory,
            the risk to development outcome was low or negligible, the
            Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: (i) strong borrower commitment; (ii) comprehensive
            planning for engineering, equipment supply, installation,
            and commissioning; and (iii) close field supervision by a
            competent owner that identified and rectified problems in a
            timely manner are key factors for a complex project such as
            this one. This project and other recently completed power
            projects in China show that construction management was
            successfully performed by the implementing agencies. Also,
            the project was explicitly designed to pilot new approaches
            to meet environmental requirements at minimum cost,
            restructuring the power sector, and utilizing private sector
            finance. Piloting has been the feature characteristic of
            Chinese reforms. Finally, several positive, systemic lessons
            for Bank supervision were identified in the QAG review: (a)
            an experienced, knowledgeable, and cohesive team is
            beneficial to project implementation; (b) continuity is
            important in ensuring effective supervision and establishing
            good rapport with counterparts; and (c) supervision of
            multiple projects in the same country or sector by the same
            team is cost-effective.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Waigaogiao Thermal Power Project :
            seventh quality of supervision assessment (QSA7) - summary
            assessment sheet

abstracts.cdata!:
The quality of supervision of the
            Shanghai Waigaoqiao Thermal Power Project was judged to be
            highly satisfactory: overall and provided an example of very
            good supervision practice. The quality of supervision
            throughout this final period of project implementation i.e.
            the seventh and eighth years since Board approval, was
            pragmatic, well-focused and solutions-oriented. Almost all
            the main development objectives have now been
            achieved-namely, the commissioning of two large, coal-fired
            thermal plants-despite an extensive delay at start up; the
            adoption of the "bubble concept" approach to
            controlling atmospheric pollution for the first time in the
            developing world, despite initial skepticism by the company
            and some local authorities; a reform program for the power
            company that went beyond that envisaged at appraisal; and
            the successful mobilization of financing for the power
            sector from international markets. Several positive,
            systemic lessons for Bank supervision more generally emerge
            from this review. First, the project benefited from an
            experienced supervision team that knew the power sector in
            China very well. Second, continuity in Bank staff working on
            a project is important in ensuring good supervision. The
            supervision team was also cohesive; all the members had a
            deep institutional knowledge of the power sector in China
            and have been working as a team on other projects. The
            supervision results demonstrate the team's high
            professionalism and the good rapport and working
            relationship established with their project counterparts.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Waigaoqiao Phase II Power Plant
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
To meet power demands, the second phase
            of the Waigaoqiao Power Plant Project will increase
            generating capacity by constructing two coal-fired
            supercritical units. A third and final phrase of installing
            additional capacity will follow. This environmental
            assessment was prepared to supplement an earlier draft
            report submitted by the East China Electric Power Design
            Institute (ECEPDI) to further address the impacts of the
            project, particularly as they relate to current and future
            power production at the Waigaoqiao facility. Mitigation of
            air pollution takes the form of emissions controls and
            emissions offsets. A high-efficiency electrostatic
            precipitator (ESP) will be installed to reduce particle
            emissions from the plant to acceptable levels. Particle
            emissions from coal and ash handling and storage activities
            will be controlled by using covered conveyors, watering, and
            air pollution control equipment. The dust control program
            from Phase I will continue to minimize emissions from
            general traffic. Bottom ash will be slurried with recycled
            water eliminating dusting conditions. Fly ash disposed of in
            an ash yard will be humidified, reducing the potential for
            fugitive particulate emissions. Sulphur dioxide emissions
            will be mitigated by using low-sulphur coal. Emissions of
            nitrogen oxides will be mitigated by using low-nitrogen
            oxide- derivative burners, a technology incorporated into
            modern boiler designs. Mitigation of negative impacts on
            water resources includes: wastewater treatment using
            neutralization and sedimentation; oil-separation employed
            for water with the potential for oil contamination; cooling
            water treated with chlorine for biological control to
            minimize chlorine residue; treated wastewater will be
            discharged with cooling water at predetermined dilution
            percentages; other low volume wastewaters such as
            oil-contaminated water, boiling cleaning wastewater, and
            bottom ash sluice water will be recycled after treatment;
            rainwater in the ash yards will be diverted to the settling
            basins at sufficient capacity to obviate the need for
            discharge; and non-contact rainfall runoff will go to
            settling ponds for discharge. Ash disposal will be mitigated
            by its reuse. Impacts associated with resettlement will be
            mitigated according to World Bank operational directives and
            the country s relevant laws and regulations, and possibly
            include job replacement and/or compensation. Finally, the
            comprehensive monitoring program for Phase I, which measures
            the air, water, ash, and occupational conditions, will
            continue in Phase II during both construction and
            operational periods. Specifically, during construction,
            environmental monitoring of dust emissions, runoff, and
            solid wastes will be performed. Any construction discharge
            will be monitored for pH, total suspended solids, and other
            parameters. Noise; emissions and ambient air quality; the
            quality of raw water, service water, and wastewater
            discharged to the environment; and periodic safety training
            and the use of primary personnel protection measures will be monitored.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Waigaoqiao Thermal Power Project is
            intended to: 1) increase electricity supply to reduce the
            acute power shortages in Shanghai through development of two
            very large coal-fired super-critical thermal units; 2)
            develop a program to apply for the first time in China the
            "bubble concept" for cost effective air quality
            management within Shanghai Municipality; 3) support the
            ongoing power sector reform by restructuring Shanghai
            Municipal Electric Power Company (SMEPC) in line with the
            power sector reform strategy; increasing private sector
            involvement through listing of the generation company; and
            adjusting the tariff level to accommodate the stricter
            sulfur dioxide emission standards; and 4) promote an
            innovative and diversified financing model for large
            infrastructure projects and improve the access of power
            entities to international financial markets.  The project
            will include the following components: (i) investment; (ii)
            environmental protection; (iii) power sector reform; and
            (iv) institutional development.
